title: Session Fixation At Logout /Session Misconfiguration

profile.name: Gratipay
profile.about: Gratitude? Gratipay! The easiest way for your company to pay for open source.

vulnerability_information:
Dear Suppport Team ,
Commonly After Logout time , session  should destroy and then new session should be created ..
But in your application , it is  not possible and same sessioncookie is there before logout and after logout   from your application  .  For further details please find the  attachment.... 


Ragards,
a23
vulnerability_information_html:
Dear Suppport Team ,
Commonly After Logout time , session should destroy and then new session should be created ..
But in your application , it is not possible and same sessioncookie is there before logout and after logout from your application . For further details please find the attachment....

activities.message:
Dear Suppport Team ,
Commonly After Logout time , session should destroy and then new session * cookie should be created ..
But in your application , it is not happening and same session cookie is there before logout and after logout from your application . For further details please find the attachment....

Ragards,
a23
activities.markdown_message:
Dear Suppport Team ,
Commonly After Logout time , session should destroy and then new session * cookie should be created ..
But in your application , it is not happening and same session cookie is there before logout and after logout from your application . For further details please find the attachment....

Ragards,
a23

activities.message:
Dear @aa23,

First off, thank you very much for your report. We appreciate the time you take to test our platform. On top of that, the screenshots are a big help.

Now concerning the issue: As far as I can tell, sessions are invalidated when the user logs out and the session ID is changed on the next login, so there is no need for the session ID to be changed or destroyed on logout.

# Steps I took
---

I am usually on your side reporting vulnerabilities to companies, but recently Gratipay requested I join their blue team. Therefore I know that when getting a response from a team, it's nice to see how they investigated the report.

In the screenshot I see you have the `EditThisCookie` extension and would highly recommend using that in order to follow along.

### 1) Login to your Gratipay account.

You will get a new session ID. Keep note of that session ID.

### 2) Logout of your account.

As you noted the session ID remains the same.

### 3) Login to your Gratipay account again.

Once again a new session ID is generated. Use the export function in `EditThisCookie`.

### 4) Logout of your account and use the import function in `EditThisCookie`.

You should not be able to login using the same session ID.

If for some reason you are able to hijack a session using a different method, please let us know.

Wishing you a merry Christmas. ‚òÉÔ∏èüéÖ‚ùÑÔ∏è

Yours sincerely,
Ed
activities.markdown_message:
Dear @aa23,

First off, thank you very much for your report. We appreciate the time you take to test our platform. On top of that, the screenshots are a big help.

Now concerning the issue: As far as I can tell, sessions are invalidated when the user logs out and the session ID is changed on the next login, so there is no need for the session ID to be changed or destroyed on logout.

Steps I took

I am usually on your side reporting vulnerabilities to companies, but recently Gratipay requested I join their blue team. Therefore I know that when getting a response from a team, it's nice to see how they investigated the report.

In the screenshot I see you have the EditThisCookie extension and would highly recommend using that in order to follow along.

1) Login to your Gratipay account.

You will get a new session ID. Keep note of that session ID.

2) Logout of your account.

As you noted the session ID remains the same.

3) Login to your Gratipay account again.

Once again a new session ID is generated. Use the export function in EditThisCookie.

4) Logout of your account and use the import function in EditThisCookie.

You should not be able to login using the same session ID.

If for some reason you are able to hijack a session using a different method, please let us know.

Wishing you a merry Christmas. ‚òÉÔ∏èüéÖ‚ùÑÔ∏è

Yours sincerely,
Ed

activities.message:
Hi @aa23,

I understand your concern, but as mentioned before sessions are invalidated when the user logs out and the session ID is changed on the next login, so there is no need for the session ID to be changed or destroyed on logout.

Would you mind logging back in and seeing whether you have the same session ID?

I invite @whit537 to join me and hopefully we can get to the bottom of this.

Best regards,
Ed
activities.markdown_message:

Would you mind logging back in and seeing whether you have the same session ID?

I invite @whit537 to join me and hopefully we can get to the bottom of this.

Best regards,
Ed

activities.message: I am terribly sorry if I am misunderstanding your point. I want to get to the bottom of this. Would you mind at least answering this question: When you logout and still have the same session ID, are you able to access a page that is only visible in an authenticated session (i.e., https://gratipay.com/~username/settings/)?

activities.message:
OK, I understand the confusion now. Thank you very much for submitting a video to demonstrate your steps.

This is not session fixation. What is happening is you log in to Gratipay using your Google account and since you are still logged in to your Google account it authenticates and logs you back in. If you were to log out of your Google account, you wouldn't be allowed to log in anymore.

Give it a go:

1) Log in to Gratipay.
2) Log out of Gratipay.
3) Log out of Google.
4) Try signing in to Gratipay.

Session fixation would mean that after you log out:

- You are still able to access a page that is only visible in an authenticated session.
- If you submit the old session ID with `EditThisCookie`, you can hijack the old session.
activities.markdown_message:
OK, I understand the confusion now. Thank you very much for submitting a video to demonstrate your steps.

This is not session fixation. What is happening is you log in to Gratipay using your Google account and since you are still logged in to your Google account it authenticates and logs you back in. If you were to log out of your Google account, you wouldn't be allowed to log in anymore.

Give it a go:

1) Log in to Gratipay.
2) Log out of Gratipay.
3) Log out of Google.
4) Try signing in to Gratipay.

Session fixation would mean that after you log out:

  • You are still able to access a page that is only visible in an authenticated session.
  • If you submit the old session ID with EditThisCookie, you can hijack the old session.

activities.message:
@aa23 I can assure you that there are no issues here.

1) If you sign out of your Gmail account (just like in the video), you will be prompted to log in again on Gratipay.

2) In future, please, share screen captures through private links to unlisted videos (e.g., vimeo).

Would you mind publicly disclosing this report?

activities.message:
Hi @aa23,

It turns out according to Gratipay's policy this report should be fully disclosed.

> Please note that, as an [open organization](http://inside.gratipay.com/big-picture/welcome), our policy is to [fully disclose](http://inside.gratipay.com/appendices/disclosures) all resolved, informative, and not applicable issues, in the interest of openness and transparency for our customers.

Best regards,
Ed
